[.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>The <code>index.html</code> file you have is a standard setup for a Vite + React project in a development environment. However, for a production build (like for deployment on GitHub Pages), the reference to <code>src/main.jsx</code> in the <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tag is typically handled differently.</p><p>In a Vite project, during the build process (<code>npm run build</code>), Vite should automatically update <code>index.html</code> in the <code>dist</code> or <code>build</code> directory. It replaces the development script tag (<code>src/main.jsx</code>) with a reference to the compiled JavaScript bundle. This updated <code>index.html</code> is the one that should be used for deployment, not the original <code>index.html</code> in your project's root.</p><h3>Ensuring Correct Build Output:</h3><ol><li><p><strong>Build Your Project</strong>:</p><ul><li>Run <code>npm run build</code> in your project directory.</li><li>This should create a <code>dist</code> directory (by default) with the production build of your application.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Check the <code>dist/index.html</code></strong>:</p><ul><li>After the build process completes, open the <code>dist/index.html</code>.</li><li>This file should no longer reference <code>src/main.jsx</code>. Instead, it should have a <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tag pointing to a compiled <code>.js</code> file (the filename will usually be a hash for cache-busting).</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Do Not Manually Edit the Development <code>index.html</code></strong>:</p><ul><li>The <code>index.html</code> in your project's root (or <code>public</code> directory) is for development purposes. You should not need to manually edit this file to point to <code>.js</code> files for production.</li><li>Any necessary changes for production should be handled automatically by the build tool (Vite).</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Deploy the Content of <code>dist</code></strong>:</p><ul><li>When deploying to GitHub Pages, ensure that the contents of the <code>dist</code> directory are pushed to your GitHub repository.</li><li>These are the files that should be served by GitHub Pages, not the development files in your project's root.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Verify GitHub Pages Configuration</strong>:</p><ul><li>In your GitHub repository settings, under the "Pages" section, make sure you are deploying from the correct branch (e.g., <code>main</code>) and the correct directory (<code>/</code> or <code>/dist</code>).</li></ul></li></ol><p>If you've done all this and the <code>dist/index.html</code> still incorrectly references <code>src/main.jsx</code>, there might be a configuration issue with Vite or a problem with how the build process is being executed. In such cases, reviewing Vite's documentation or seeking support from the Vite community can provide more specific guidance.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start gap-3 text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>To commit your updated <code>.gitignore</code> file to your Git repository, you can follow these steps:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Stage the Changes</strong>:</p><ul><li>First, stage the updated <code>.gitignore</code> file for commit. Open your terminal or command line, navigate to your project's root directory, and run:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add .gitignore
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Commit the Changes</strong>:</p><ul><li>Next, commit the changes to the repository with a meaningful commit message. For example:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Update .gitignore to track dist directory"</span>
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Push the Commit to Your Remote Repository</strong>:</p><ul><li>Finally, push the commit to your remote repository (such as GitHub). If you're using the <code>main</code> branch, the command would be:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git push origin main
</code></div></div></pre></li><li>Replace <code>main</code> with the name of the branch you are working on if it's different.</li></ul></li></ol><p>These commands will update your local and remote repositories with the changes to the <code>.gitignore</code> file. Once this is done, Git will start tracking any changes in the <code>dist</code> directory, allowing you to commit and push these as part of your deployment process.</p></div></div></div><div text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>The error message you're encountering, "Failed to load module script: Expected a JavaScript module script but the server responded with a MIME type of 'text/jsx'", typically occurs when a web server attempts to serve a <code>.jsx</code> file directly to the browser. Browsers expect JavaScript files with a MIME type of <code>text/javascript</code>, but <code>.jsx</code> files, which are specific to React, are not natively understood by browsers and need to be compiled into regular <code>.js</code> files.</p><p>Given that you're deploying to GitHub Pages, which serves static files only, all React <code>.jsx</code> files need to be transpiled into <code>.js</code> files as part of the build process. Here’s what you should do:</p><h3>1. <strong>Check Your Build Output</strong>:</h3><ul><li>Make sure you have run the build process (<code>npm run build</code>) and it completes successfully. This process should generate a <code>dist</code> or <code>build</code> directory with the compiled JavaScript files.</li><li>After the build, the <code>index.html</code> in your <code>dist</code> or <code>build</code> directory should reference <code>.js</code> files (not <code>.jsx</code> files).</li></ul><h3>2. <strong>Inspect Your <code>index.html</code> in the Build Output</strong>:</h3><ul><li>Open the <code>index.html</code> file in your <code>dist</code> or <code>build</code> directory and verify that it is pointing to compiled <code>.js</code> files.</li><li>The script tags should not reference any <code>.jsx</code> files.</li></ul><h3>3. <strong>Commit and Push the Build Output to GitHub</strong>:</h3><ul><li>If the <code>dist</code> or <code>build</code> directory is updated correctly and not ignored (as per your <code>.gitignore</code>), add, commit, and push it to your repository:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add dist -f <span class="hljs-comment"># Or 'build' if that's your output directory</span>
git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Deploy latest build"</span>
git push origin main <span class="hljs-comment"># Replace 'main' with your branch name if different</span>
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul><h3>4. <strong>Ensure Correct Deployment Settings on GitHub</strong>:</h3><ul><li>In your GitHub repository settings, under the "Pages" section, make sure you're deploying from the correct branch and directory (<code>/dist</code> or <code>/build</code> as per your configuration).</li></ul><h3>5. <strong>Clear Browser Cache and Check Again</strong>:</h3><ul><li>After pushing your changes, give GitHub Pages a few minutes to update. Then, clear your browser cache or use an incognito window to check your site.</li></ul><h3>6. <strong>Review Your Source <code>index.html</code></strong>:</h3><ul><li>The <code>index.html</code> in your project’s root or <code>public</code> folder is the source file for development and should reference <code>src/main.jsx</code>.</li><li>Ensure that during development, this file is correct, but for production, the <code>index.html</code> in your build output directory should be used.</li></ul><p>By ensuring that your build process is running correctly and that the build output is being deployed, you should be able to resolve the MIME type issue. The key is to make sure that <code>.jsx</code> files are being compiled into <code>.js</code> files, and that the browser is loading these compiled files from your build output directory.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start gap-3 empty:hidden"><div class="text-gray-400 flex self-end lg:self-center justify-center lg:justify-start mt-0 gap-1 [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>If the <code>dist</code> directory is not present in your <code>main</code> branch on GitHub, and you need it for deploying your site on GitHub Pages, you'll need to add and push it to your repository. Here's how you can do that:</p><h3>1. <strong>Build Your Project</strong>:</h3><ul><li>First, make sure you have run the build process to generate the <code>dist</code> directory. If you're using a tool like Vite or Create React App, this is typically done with:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">npm run build
</code></div></div></pre></li><li>This command should create the <code>dist</code> directory with all your compiled and production-ready files.</li></ul><h3>2. <strong>Remove <code>dist</code> from .gitignore</strong> (If Needed):</h3><ul><li>If the <code>dist</code> directory is listed in your <code>.gitignore</code> file, remove it from there. This will allow Git to track the changes in this directory.</li><li>Update the <code>.gitignore</code> file to not include <code>dist</code>, save the file, and then stage and commit this change:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add .gitignore
git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Update .gitignore to include dist directory"</span>
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul><h3>3. <strong>Add the <code>dist</code> Directory to Git</strong>:</h3><ul><li>Force add the <code>dist</code> directory to your repository:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add dist -f
</code></div></div></pre></li><li>The <code>-f</code> or <code>--force</code> flag is used to add the files even if they're in the <code>.gitignore</code>.</li></ul><h3>4. <strong>Commit the Changes</strong>:</h3><ul><li>Commit the <code>dist</code> directory to your repository:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Add dist directory for GitHub Pages deployment"</span>
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul><h3>5. <strong>Push to GitHub</strong>:</h3><ul><li>Push the changes to your <code>main</code> branch:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git push origin main
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul><h3>6. <strong>Check Your GitHub Repository</strong>:</h3><ul><li>After pushing, check your GitHub repository to ensure that the <code>dist</code> directory has been successfully uploaded.</li><li>If you have GitHub Actions or other CI/CD processes, ensure there are no errors.</li></ul><h3>7. <strong>Configure GitHub Pages</strong>:</h3><ul><li>Go to the settings of your GitHub repository, find the "Pages" section, and make sure it's configured to serve from the <code>main</code> branch. If your build output is in the <code>dist</code> directory, you might need to adjust the source settings accordingly.</li></ul><h3>8. <strong>Verify the Deployment</strong>:</h3><ul><li>GitHub Pages might take a few minutes to update your site after you push the changes.</li><li>Once it's done, visit your GitHub Pages URL to see your updated site.</li></ul><p>By following these steps, you should be able to successfully deploy your site on GitHub Pages using the contents of the <code>dist</code> directory. Remember to clear your browser cache when checking the updated site to avoid loading an older version.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start gap-3 empty:hidden"><div screenshot, the source is set to deploy from the <code>main</code> branch and the root folder (<code>/</code>). This means GitHub Pages is looking for the <code>index.html</code> file directly in the root of your <code>main</code> branch, not inside any subdirectories like <code>dist</code>.</p><p>If your build process generates the <code>index.html</code> and other site assets in the <code>dist</code> directory, you need to adjust the source settings in the GitHub Pages section to point to the <code>dist</code> directory. Here's what you should do:</p><ol><li>In the <strong>"Source"</strong> section of the GitHub Pages settings, change the folder from <strong>"/ (root)"</strong> to <strong>"/dist"</strong> or whatever folder name your build outputs to.</li><li>Click <strong>"Save"</strong> to apply the changes.</li></ol><p>After making this change, GitHub Pages will serve the content from the <code>dist</code> directory of your <code>main</code> branch. Give it a few minutes to process, and then check your GitHub Pages URL to see if the site is live. data-message-author-role="assistant" data-message-id="3304fe77-ba86-45ff-9d11-4c63d86f02dd" class="min-h-[20px] text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>If the <code>dist</code> directory has been pushed to your GitHub repository but does not appear as an option in the GitHub Pages source settings, it could be due to a delay in GitHub's system updating the settings options or a caching issue within the GitHub UI.</p><p>Here are a few steps you can take to troubleshoot:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Refresh the Repository Settings Page</strong>:</p><ul><li>Sometimes the UI does not immediately reflect the current state of the repository. Try refreshing the page or clearing your browser cache and then checking the settings again.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Verify the <code>dist</code> Directory in the Repository</strong>:</p><ul><li>Double-check the <code>main</code> branch of your repository to confirm that the <code>dist</code> directory is present and contains the files you expect.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Wait a Few Minutes</strong>:</p><ul><li>After pushing new content, especially something like a new directory that's used for GitHub Pages, there can sometimes be a slight delay before it's recognized as an available option in the settings.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Check if GitHub Pages Is Building</strong>:</p><ul><li>Look for any indication that a GitHub Pages build is in progress. This could be a status message in the settings or an ongoing workflow in the "Actions" tab.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Try Using Another Browser or Incognito Mode</strong>:</p><ul><li>Occasionally, the problem might be with the browser. Try using a different browser or opening an incognito/private browsing window to access the repository settings.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Confirm the <code>dist</code> Directory is Not Empty</strong>:</p><ul><li>GitHub Pages will not recognize a directory if it is empty. Ensure that your <code>dist</code> directory has been committed with its contents, not just the directory itself.</li></ul></li></ol><p>If none of these steps make the <code>dist</code> directory available as an option in the GitHub Pages settings, and you are certain that the directory exists in your repository with the correct content, consider reaching out to GitHub support for assistance. They can help troubleshoot issues that might be related to the platform itself.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start gap-3 empty:hidden"><div class="text-gray-400 flex self-end class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>No, if your <code>dist</code> directory contains an <code>assets</code> folder with files in it, then the <code>dist</code> directory is not empty. GitHub Pages should recognize it as long as the contents are pushed to your repository. Here's what you can ensure:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Check that <code>dist</code> is Committed</strong>:</p><ul><li>Confirm that the <code>dist</code> directory and its contents (including the <code>assets</code> folder and all files within) are committed to the repository. Sometimes, Git can ignore directories if they contain only empty subdirectories or if there's a <code>.gitignore</code> rule preventing them from being committed.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Confirm <code>dist</code> is Pushed to the Correct Branch</strong>:</p><ul><li>Make sure that the <code>dist</code> directory is pushed to the same branch that GitHub Pages is configured to deploy from (often the <code>main</code> branch).</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Inspect the Repository on GitHub</strong>:</p><ul><li>Visit your repository on GitHub and manually inspect the file tree to ensure that the <code>dist</code> directory, along with its contents, is present on the expected branch.</li></ul></li></ol><p>If you've confirmed these points and the <code>dist</code> directory is still not showing up as an option in the GitHub Pages settings, you might want to try the following additional steps:</p><ul><li><p><strong>Push Again</strong>:
If you're unsure whether the <code>dist</code> directory was properly pushed, try pushing it again:</p><pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add dist -f
git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Recommit dist directory"</span>
git push origin main
</code></div></div></pre></li><li><p><strong>Check for GitHub Pages Deployment Errors</strong>:
Sometimes, if there's an error in deploying your site, GitHub Pages will not update the source settings correctly. Check the "Actions" tab for any error messages related to the deployment.</p></li><li><p><strong>Contact GitHub Support</strong>:
If you're certain everything is set up correctly and you're still facing the issue, it may be worth contacting GitHub support for help with the repository settings.</p></li></ul></div></div></div><div [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>The <code>dist-ssr</code> entry in your <code>.gitignore</code> file is specifically for ignoring a directory typically associated with server-side rendering (SSR) artifacts. This would not impact the <code>dist</code> directory unless you have a setup where SSR outputs are being placed into the <code>dist</code> directory and you've inadvertently named it <code>dist-ssr</code>.</p><p>If your build process generates a <code>dist</code> directory for client-side assets and does not touch <code>dist-ssr</code>, then the <code>dist-ssr</code> entry in your <code>.gitignore</code> should have no effect on your <code>dist</code> directory being tracked by Git.</p><p>To ensure that your <code>dist</code> directory is correctly tracked and not ignored, it should not be listed in your <code>.gitignore</code>. If it's present in <code>.gitignore</code>, remove that line, commit the change, and push it to your repository:</p><pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash"><span class="hljs-comment"># Edit .gitignore to remove the line with 'dist' if it's there</span>

git add .gitignore
git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Ensure dist directory is not ignored"</span>
git push origin main
</code></div></div></pre><p>After this, make sure that your <code>dist</code> directory is added to your repository:</p><pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add dist -f
git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Add dist directory with -f flag"</span>
git push origin main
</code></div></div></pre><p>The <code>-f</code> or <code>--force</code> flag will force Git to add the <code>dist</code> directory even if it was previously ignored. Make sure you commit and push this change so that the <code>dist</code> directory shows up on GitHub.</p><p>Once <code>dist</code> is pushed to GitHub, check your GitHub Pages settings again to see if it appears as an option for the source directory. If it still doesn't show up and you have confirmed that <code>dist</code> is on GitHub, then the problem might be on the GitHub side, and reaching out to GitHub Support might be the next best step.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start gap-3 empty:hidden"><div class="text-gray-400 flex self-end lg:self-center justify-center lg:justify-start mt-0 gap-1 visible"><button text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>If your <code>master</code> branch is still active and you intended to use the <code>main</code> branch for GitHub Pages, this could indeed be part of the issue. GitHub Pages will only deploy from the branch you specify in the repository settings, so if <code>dist</code> is on a different branch than the one configured for Pages, it won't be deployed.</p><p>Here's how you can align everything:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Check Which Branch GitHub Pages is Set to Use:</strong></p><ul><li>Go to your repository settings on GitHub.</li><li>Scroll down to the "Pages" section and check which branch is set as the source for GitHub Pages.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Ensure <code>dist</code> is on the Correct Branch:</strong></p><ul><li>If GitHub Pages is set to deploy from <code>main</code> but your <code>dist</code> directory is on <code>master</code>, you'll need to merge <code>master</code> into <code>main</code> or change the source branch for Pages to <code>master</code>.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>To Merge <code>master</code> into <code>main</code>:</strong></p><ul><li>Switch to the <code>main</code> branch:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git checkout main
</code></div></div></pre></li><li>Merge the changes from <code>master</code>:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git merge master
</code></div></div></pre></li><li>Resolve any merge conflicts if they exist.</li><li>Push the updated <code>main</code> branch:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git push origin main
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul></li><li><p><strong>To Change the Source Branch for GitHub Pages:</strong></p><ul><li>If you want to deploy from <code>master</code> instead, you can change the source branch in the GitHub Pages settings to <code>master</code>.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Push <code>dist</code> to the Correct Branch:</strong></p><ul><li>Ensure that the <code>dist</code> directory is committed and pushed to the branch you're using for deployment on GitHub Pages.</li><li>Use the <code>-f</code> flag to force the addition of the <code>dist</code> directory if necessary:<pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git add dist -f
git commit -m <span class="hljs-string">"Add dist directory for deployment"</span>
git push origin [branch-name] <span class="hljs-comment"># Replace [branch-name] with 'main' or 'master'.</span>
</code></div></div></pre></li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Verify the Branch Settings:</strong></p><ul><li>After making these changes, verify that the <code>dist</code> directory is present in the branch configured for GitHub Pages and that the settings reflect the correct branch.</li></ul></li></ol><p>Remember, it's important to consistently use one branch as the source for GitHub Pages to avoid confusion and deployment issues. If you've recently renamed <code>master</code> to <code>main</code>, ensure that all your local and remote settings are updated accordingly.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>Changing the default branch on GitHub from <code>master</code> to <code>main</code> can be done from the repository settings, but the option might not be directly under the "Branches" section depending on the UI updates GitHub may have made.</p><p>Here's how you can generally change the default branch:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Go to Your GitHub Repository</strong>:</p><ul><li>Navigate to your GitHub repository where you want to change the default branch.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Open Repository Settings</strong>:</p><ul><li>Click on the "Settings" tab for the repository.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Find the Branches Section</strong>:</p><ul><li>Scroll down or look for the section labeled "Branches". Sometimes the default branch option is under another subsection like "Repository details" or similar.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Change the Default Branch</strong>:</p><ul><li>Within the "Branches" section, you should see the current default branch listed, usually with a dropdown menu or an "Edit" button next to it.</li><li>Click on the dropdown or "Edit" button to change the default branch from <code>master</code> to <code>main</code>.</li><li>Select <code>main</code> from the dropdown list and save the change.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Confirm the Change</strong>:</p><ul><li>GitHub may ask you to confirm the change because it can have significant effects on open pull requests and other repository settings.</li></ul></li></ol><p>If you cannot find the option to change the default branch or if GitHub's interface has changed, GitHub's help documentation or their support can provide updated instructions specific to the current version of the GitHub UI.</p><p>After you've changed the default branch to <code>main</code>, ensure that your local repository is also set to use <code>main</code> as the default. You can do this with the following Git commands in your local repository:</p><pre><div class="bg-black rounded-md"><div class="flex items-center relative text-gray-200 bg-gray-800 dark:bg-token-surface-primary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between rounded-t-md"><span>bash</span><button class="flex gap-1 items-center"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="icon-sm"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M12 4C10.8954 4 10 4.89543 10 6H14C14 4.89543 13.1046 4 12 4ZM8.53513 4C9.22675 2.8044 10.5194 2 12 2C13.4806 2 14.7733 2.8044 15.4649 4H17C18.6569 4 20 5.34315 20 7V19C20 20.6569 18.6569 22 17 22H7C5.34315 22 4 20.6569 4 19V7C4 5.34315 5.34315 4 7 4H8.53513ZM8 6H7C6.44772 6 6 6.44772 6 7V19C6 19.5523 6.44772 20 7 20H17C17.5523 20 18 19.5523 18 19V7C18 6.44772 17.5523 6 17 6H16C16 7.10457 15.1046 8 14 8H10C8.89543 8 8 7.10457 8 6Z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg>Copy code</button></div><div class="p-4 overflow-y-auto"><code class="!whitespace-pre hljs language-bash">git branch -m master main
git fetch origin
git branch -u origin/main main
git remote set-head origin -a
</code></div></div></pre><p>The above commands will rename your local <code>master</code> branch to <code>main</code>, update tracking information, and set the remote default branch to <code>main</code>.</p><p>Finally, go back to the GitHub Pages settings and make sure you select <code>main</code> as the source branch for deployment.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>The active branch for your GitHub Pages deployment is specified in the settings of your GitHub repository. Here’s how you can find and potentially change it:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Navigate to Your Repository</strong>: Go to your GitHub repository where your GitHub Pages site is located.</p></li><li><p><strong>Access the Settings</strong>: Click on the "Settings" tab at the top of the repository.</p></li><li><p><strong>Go to the Pages Section</strong>: Scroll down the sidebar until you find the "Pages" section or click on the "Pages" menu item directly if it's visible in the sidebar.</p></li><li><p><strong>Check the Source Branch</strong>: In the "Pages" section, look for the "Source" setting. This displays the branch and folder that GitHub Pages is currently using to build and deploy your site.</p></li></ol><p>If you need to change the branch from which GitHub Pages builds your site, you can do so in this "Source" section. Click on the dropdown menu to select a different branch or directory (such as <code>main</code> or <code>master</code> and <code>/</code> or <code>/dist</code>), and then click "Save".</p><p>Remember that after changing the source branch, it may take a few minutes for GitHub Pages to reflect these changes. If you've just pushed a new branch or made changes, you might also need to refresh the page to see the latest options in the dropdown menu.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>In the context of GitHub, the "active branches" label in your repository's branches page typically refers to branches that have recent commits or activity. It doesn't necessarily indicate the branch that GitHub Pages uses for deployment. The "Default branch" is the one that GitHub considers the main branch for your repository, and it's shown at the top of the branches page, as indicated in your screenshot.</p><p>If you've already set <code>main</code> as the default branch and you want GitHub Pages to build from the <code>main</code> branch, you should:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Check the GitHub Pages Settings</strong>:</p><ul><li>Navigate to the repository settings by clicking the "Settings" tab in your repository.</li><li>Scroll down to the "Pages" section to see which branch GitHub Pages is configured to use.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Configure GitHub Pages Source</strong>:</p><ul><li>If GitHub Pages is not set to build from the <code>main</code> branch, you can change the source branch in the "Pages" section of your settings.</li><li>Select <code>main</code> from the dropdown menu and choose the folder (root or <code>/dist</code>, depending on your setup).</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Save the Changes</strong>:</p><ul><li>After selecting <code>main</code> and the appropriate folder, click "Save" to apply the changes.</li></ul></li></ol><p>The "Active branches" section doesn't impact the GitHub Pages deployment. It's more of an informational display about which branches have had recent activity. The deployment for GitHub Pages is controlled entirely through the "Pages" settings section.</p><p>After you make the change in the "Pages" settings, it may take a few minutes for GitHub Pages to deploy the site from the new branch. You can usually see the deployment progress in the same "Pages" section or in the "Actions" tab if you have a workflow set up for deployments.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex justify-start text-message flex flex-col items-start gap-3 whitespace-pre-wrap break-words [.text-message+&amp;]:mt-5 overflow-x-auto"><div class="markdown prose w-full break-words dark:prose-invert dark"><p>Jekyll is a simple, blog-aware, static site generator that's designed for building personal, project, or organization websites. It's widely used for creating blogs and personal websites, but it's also powerful enough to be used for documentation and other web projects.</p><p>Here's what Jekyll themes do:</p><ol><li><p><strong>Provide Design Templates</strong>:</p><ul><li>Jekyll themes include pre-made HTML templates, stylesheets, and sometimes JavaScript files that define the look and feel of a website.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Simplify Site Creation</strong>:</p><ul><li>With a theme, you don't need to create your site's design from scratch. Instead, you apply a theme to your content, and Jekyll generates the site for you using that theme's templates.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Allow Customization</strong>:</p><ul><li>Themes can be customized to suit your needs. You can override certain parts of a theme, such as the layout templates or styles, by editing the corresponding files in your Jekyll project.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Support Content Creation</strong>:</p><ul><li>Jekyll themes are often designed with content in mind. They provide layouts for blog posts, pages, and other types of content that you might want to include on your site.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Integrate with GitHub Pages</strong>:</p><ul><li>Jekyll is deeply integrated with GitHub Pages. You can select a Jekyll theme for your GitHub Pages site, and GitHub will automatically build and serve your site using Jekyll's static site generation capabilities.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Support for Markdown and Other Converters</strong>:</p><ul><li>Jekyll supports writing content in Markdown, which is a lightweight markup language that is converted to HTML by Jekyll. It also has support for other converters like Textile.</li></ul></li><li><p><strong>Extensibility with Plugins</strong>:</p><ul><li>Jekyll has a plugin system that allows you to extend its functionality, and themes can take advantage of these plugins to add new features to your site.</li></ul></li></ol><p>Using a Jekyll theme on GitHub Pages simplifies the process of setting up and maintaining a website. You can focus on writing your content, and Jekyll takes care of the rest, transforming your text into a static website that's ready to be served.</p></div></div></div><div class="mt-1 flex
